An open-source framework for automating contact-tracing

The problem

  • Healthcare workers (HCW) are at a high-risk for COVID-19 infection
  • Therefore, even if the general population is "locked-down", HCWs will act as agents of infection in their communities
  • There will be an extremely high number of infected HCWs - too many to carry out traditional, manual contact-tracing
  • But conact-tracing - knowing where HCWs went and whom they may have exposed to the illness during their infectious period - is absolutely necessary to prevent widespread disase transmission from HCWs to their communities

The solution

  • We capture HCWs' location data via GPS on their phone
  • We store these data on a server
  • When a HCW tests positive for COVID-19, a report is generated detailing his/her location history during the potentially infectious period
  • This report is used to immediately deploy contact-tracing which re-traces the locations of the HCW and carries out active case-finding

Example

  • Dr. Mary works with COVID-19 patients
  • She tests positive
  • Rather than wasting time asking her where she shops, whether she stopped at the gas station yesterday, where she walks her dog, etc. these data are pulled up immediately in a report
  • A report is automatically generated for public health authorities detailing Mary's location history
  • Using this report, a team is deployed to:
    • Notify those who may have been infected by Mary (grocery store clerk, gas station attendant, colleague who worked at same time, etc.) so they can self-isolate
    • Monitor those potential contacts for development of symptoms
    • When appropriate, carry out proactive testing on Mary's contacts

The toolset

  • Ideally, enrollment of HCWs into a locations-tracking system should be carried out by a central authority on one, centralized application
  • However, tracking is an urgent priority and needs to begin now.
  • Accordingly, we have put together a framework/guide for using open-source tools so that health agencies, hospitals, etc. can begin tracking locations immediately
  • It's imperfect and is undergoing active development. But we want to share the concept now so others can deploy, or take the tech and run with it.
  • This framework uses (a) Traccar (an open-source vehicles fleet-tracking app) for location capture, (b) R-Shiny for worker enrollment and identification management, (c) R-Markdown for report generation, and (d) MySQL for data storage

Steps

  1. You (hospital manager, health department chief, etc.) decide whether:
    • A. You want your IT team to deploy the system locally (ie, your own servers, etc.)
    • B. You want Databrew's assistance to deploy the system
  2. You act
    • A. If locally, your IT team uses the documentation HERE to deploy a system
    • B. If you require assistance, send an email to joe@databrew.cc and we will deploy a system for you
